body:
In GitLab by @asottile on Dec 23, 2019, 05:45

I think the idea is fine but playing devil's advocate: do we need this when there's already inline-ignore (`# noqa`) and `per-file-ignores`?

when we moved to establish a baseline at yelp when adopting flake8, we wrote a thing (that in retrospect probably would have been useful to open source -- but it's too late for that now that I don't work there!) that tried to apply `# noqa` comments to files with few violations, and excluded files with 100% violations (such as files which were just `*` imports or `__init__.py` files)

In GitLab by @sobolevn on Dec 23, 2019, 06:50

> do we need this when there's already inline-ignore (`# noqa`) and `per-file-ignores`?

Good point! The difference is simple. Imagine a large code base (like 100.000s lines of code) and a new linter with tons of violations. Every file will be over-floated with `noqa` and `per-file-ignores` will be too large. And you are required to analyse what is going on with each particular case, make a decision, put dozens of `noqa` here and there. It might be too long or even impossible for a human being.

But, `flake8 --create-baseline` just works. You run one command once and you are good to go. 

And one more thing. With `baseline` you can easily go further and enable (as I call it) "Refactoring mode". When you are required to reduce the violation count by the given threshold each time you commit your code. Details: https://github.com/life4/flakehell/issues/5 And possibly any other features you can imagine (like graphs, stats, burndown-charts, panning, etc) that are possible with `baseline` and are hardly possible with raw `noqa`.

My experience with `flakehell` was pleasant enough to propose this feature into the core library.

In GitLab by @sigmavirus24 on Jan 23, 2020, 17:10

> But, `flake8 --create-baseline` just works. You run one command once and you are good to go.

So I've thought about this a few times. For one thing, how we do this is tricky. That baseline file could introduce extra frustration. What if someone renames a directory or file?

My first instinct is to use per-file-ignores but we know that doesn't perform well for giant projects. If instead we used something else we could be more efficient about storage and application of the baseline.

In GitLab by @sobolevn on Mar 23, 2020, 02:55

I have started to work on this in `wemake-python-styleguide`: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/issues/1274

I am going to test this feature and then I can send a PR with the backport to `flake8` if you are interested.

In GitLab by @sobolevn on Mar 24, 2020, 01:06

Done: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/pull/1276

I invite you guys to review it if you wish! @asottile @sigmavirus24

issue.title: Invalid ignore (or select) arguments silently ignored

repository.name: flake8
repository.description: flake8 is a python tool that glues together pycodestyle, pyflakes, mccabe, and third-party plugins to check the style and quality of some python code.

issue.body:
In GitLab by @pjacock on May 1, 2017, 07:01

*Please describe how you installed Flake8*

Example:

```
$ pip3 install flake8 flake8-docstring
```

*Please provide the exact, unmodified output of `flake8 --bug-report`*

```
$ flake8 --bug-report
{
  "dependencies": [
    {
      "dependency": "setuptools",
      "version": "28.8.0"
    }
  ],
  "platform": {
    "python_implementation": "CPython",
    "python_version": "3.6.0",
    "system": "Darwin"
  },
  "plugins": [
    {
      "plugin": "flake8-docstrings",
      "version": "1.1.0, pydocstyle: 2.0.0"
    },
    {
      "plugin": "flake8_commas._base",
      "version": "0.4.3"
    },
    {
      "plugin": "mccabe",
      "version": "0.6.1"
    },
    {
      "plugin": "pycodestyle",
      "version": "2.3.1"
    },
    {
      "plugin": "pyflakes",
      "version": "1.5.0"
    }
  ],
  "version": "3.3.0"
}
```

*Please describe the problem or feature*

Accidental configuration errors are silently ignored.

*If this is a bug report, please explain with examples (and example code) what you expected to happen and what actually happened.*

Sample test file:

```
$ python3 nasty.py 
42
$ python nasty.py 
42
$ cat nasty.py 
"""Test case for flake8 with some deliberate bad style."""


#bad spacing, and docstring issues too
def add(x,y):
    ''' this is a pointless function which will add two variables together
    withouth making any assumptions about their type '''
    return x+y


print(add(40, 2))
```

Running flake8 in isolated mode to show all possible warnings including E226:

```
$ flake8 nasty.py --isolated --ignore ""
nasty.py:4:1: E265 block comment should start with '# '
nasty.py:5:1: D205 1 blank line required between summary line and description
nasty.py:5:1: D209 Multi-line docstring closing quotes should be on a separate line
nasty.py:5:1: D210 No whitespaces allowed surrounding docstring text
nasty.py:5:1: D300 Use """triple double quotes"""
nasty.py:5:1: D400 First line should end with a period
nasty.py:5:1: D401 First line should be in imperative mood; try rephrasing
nasty.py:5:1: D403 First word of the first line should be properly capitalized
nasty.py:5:10: E231 missing whitespace after ','
nasty.py:8:13: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
```

Running flake8 with a well formed ignore list:

```
$ flake8 nasty.py --isolated --ignore "E265,D2,D4"
nasty.py:5:1: D300 Use """triple double quotes"""
nasty.py:5:10: E231 missing whitespace after ','
nasty.py:8:13: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
```

Running flake8 with a malformed ignore list:

```
$ flake8 nasty.py --isolated --ignore "E265,D2 D4"
nasty.py:5:1: D205 1 blank line required between summary line and description
nasty.py:5:1: D209 Multi-line docstring closing quotes should be on a separate line
nasty.py:5:1: D210 No whitespaces allowed surrounding docstring text
nasty.py:5:1: D300 Use """triple double quotes"""
nasty.py:5:1: D400 First line should end with a period
nasty.py:5:1: D401 First line should be in imperative mood; try rephrasing
nasty.py:5:1: D403 First word of the first line should be properly capitalized
nasty.py:5:10: E231 missing whitespace after ','
nasty.py:8:13: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
```

Expected result here would be an error about the ignore list.

Actual result was as for:

```
$ flake8 nasty.py --isolated --ignore "E265"
nasty.py:5:1: D205 1 blank line required between summary line and description
nasty.py:5:1: D209 Multi-line docstring closing quotes should be on a separate line
nasty.py:5:1: D210 No whitespaces allowed surrounding docstring text
nasty.py:5:1: D300 Use """triple double quotes"""
nasty.py:5:1: D400 First line should end with a period
nasty.py:5:1: D401 First line should be in imperative mood; try rephrasing
nasty.py:5:1: D403 First word of the first line should be properly capitalized
nasty.py:5:10: E231 missing whitespace after ','
nasty.py:8:13: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
```

The command line version is annoying, but the configuration file case is more easily triggered:

```
$ cat flake8_good 
[flake8]
ignore=
    E265,
    D2,
    D4
$ flake8 nasty.py --config flake8_good 
nasty.py:5:1: D300 Use """triple double quotes"""
nasty.py:5:10: E231 missing whitespace after ','
nasty.py:8:13: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
```

vs:

```
$ cat flake8_bad 
[flake8]
ignore=
    E265,
    D2
    D4
$ flake8 nasty.py --config flake8_bad
nasty.py:5:1: D205 1 blank line required between summary line and description
nasty.py:5:1: D209 Multi-line docstring closing quotes should be on a separate line
nasty.py:5:1: D210 No whitespaces allowed surrounding docstring text
nasty.py:5:1: D300 Use """triple double quotes"""
nasty.py:5:1: D400 First line should end with a period
nasty.py:5:1: D401 First line should be in imperative mood; try rephrasing
nasty.py:5:1: D403 First word of the first line should be properly capitalized
nasty.py:5:10: E231 missing whitespace after ','
nasty.py:8:13: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
```

Here as per http://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/configuration.html#configuration I am deliberately using multiple lines for the ignore list (and would actually have comments in here too).

issue.title: Filter out empty ignore/select codes - [merged]

repository.name: flake8
repository.description: flake8 is a python tool that glues together pycodestyle, pyflakes, mccabe, and third-party plugins to check the style and quality of some python code.

issue.body:
In GitLab by @sigmavirus24 on May 20, 2017, 18:30

_Merges bug/330 -> master_

When we parse out our comma separated lists, we should ignore empty
strings to avoid them breaking users' expectations.

Closes #330

body:
Before this gets lost, it looks like the baseline feature will not be implemented in wemake-python-styleguide, so someone will probably need to volunteer to reimplement the code in flake8 directly.

I no longer need the baseline functionality, so don't plan to do further development on it. However, I used it on a project for several months and am confident that it's ready for a public release. If someone wants to take on the port to flake8, my PR to wemake is available and I'm happy to answer any questions about it: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/pull/1471

There are a few additional ideas that could be implemented to improve future releases (in particular see [#1276 (comment)](https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/pull/1276#issuecomment-646757232) and the disabled all_change test: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/pull/1471/files#diff-d0914f16c784a2349a4008ccc24c17220012a08741e8c54f290c74dd488efaa1R148).
fwiw it's unlikely to be implemented here given `per-file-ignores` can already be leveraged to a similar intent and the complexity for a true baseline doesn't seem worth it

I think the baseline provides a lot of advantages over `per-file-ignores` when it comes to adding flake8 to an existing project. You can check the whole project and ensure that no new violations are added while slowly improving the codebase. I was using this on a 30k+ line project with 1000s of violations, and cleaned up ~25% of violations without even trying. `per-file-ignores` would have been entirely useless on this project.

Of course, I'm not the one that has to deal with maintaining this project after merging such a feature.. so, I guess the only option for anyone wanting to take this on is a separate plugin for baseline alone. Again, just send me a message if you're interested and have any questions about the code in that PR.
I think the better solution is to just use a code formatter to fix the problems

If you have a formatter which can fix all flake8 violations, then you might as well stop using flake8. :P

We used a lot of extra plugins, so I highly doubt a formatter would have fixed the majority of violations (in fact, I recall we were using black, so the flake8 violations were mostly not style violations).
